author: borntoperform
body: As someone who's worked in cybersecurity for a decade now, Fortinet's products absolutely suck. There are parallels with Symantec/McAfee, products that everyone knows is bottom of the barrel but they make so much money because they will charge so little that customers will simply renew, even though there are better products on the market.

author: IvanSkavar
body:
Cash of $1,969,000

Accounts payable of $1,739,000

Operating loss of $4,065,000 (just Q4).

Subsequent to the year ended November 30, 2019, the company entered into a contract of sale for commercial real estate. The agreement is in the amount of $1,125,000 and still remains subject to closing.

[March/17/2020](https://www.globenewswire.com/news-release/2020/03/17/2001869/0/en/GTEC-Enters-into-Term-Sheet-for-4-5-Million-Debt-Financing.html) \- $4,500,000 at 9.5%. The proceeds of the loan will be used for an early repayment of the Company’s existing $3,700,000 senior secured loan (maturing June 11, 2020) and general working capital. Trichome will also be issued common shares of GTEC in an amount equal to 16.05% of the Net Loan Proceeds - at $0.09/share or whatever the share price, which ever is lower (max 11,000,000 shares).

At 136M shares that's not nothing.

Norton Singhavon waiving his rights to money left and right (multiple mid single millions) to keep the doors open and the presses printing. This business model will work if revenue explodes in the next quarter...otherwise...I think they're in quite a tight spot.

|Q ending|Revenue|Operating Loss|
|:-|:-|:-|
|Nov/31/2019|$1,128,000|$4,065,000  |
|Aug/30/2019|$1,031,000|$1,147,000|
|May/31/2019|$109,000|$1,491,000|
|Feb/28/2019|$93,000|$1,595,000|

\~

Am I missing anything there?

author: chthonian_chaffinch
body:
Certain events (special dividends, stock splits, reverse splits, mergers, etc) trigger a contract adjustment, which affects the details of the contract.

In this case, NLOK paid a special dividend of $12/share, which was reflected in the stock price.

For example, say you owned 1 share of NLOK:

* Just before the dividend, you own 1 share worth $28.41 (total value = $28.41)
* Just after, your share is only worth $16.41, but you have a $12 cash payment coming (total value = $28.41)

The value of your investment hasn't changed - the drastic price drop simply reflects the dividend payment. Similarly, contracts are adjusted to reflect that dividend.

* 1 pre-dividend (old) share is equal to 1 post-dividend (new) share plus $12
   * The current price ($17.21) is like an 'old' price of $29.21
* 1 old put is a contract that allows you to sell 100 'old' shares at the strike price ($28)
   * 'old' shares don't exist, but they're equivalent to 1 new share, plus $12
   * As such, the contract allows you to sell 100 'new' shares plus $1200 for $2800

In other words, your new break even price is $15.04 ($28 strike - $12 dividend - $0.96 premium). You're not ITM right now (current price is $17.21), but if you're able to sell that at a profit, I'd take it, and open a new position if you still think it's still a good position to hold.

author: abecedarius
body:
Which online brokers properly support two-factor authentication on login? That is, not by SMS?

I'm asking because I was just starting to sign up with Vanguard, then found out that while they have a Yubikey option, [their site says](https://investor.vanguard.com/security/security-codes) "when you obtain a security key, you'll also sign up for security codes so that you can still access your account if you don't have your key with you." So can any SIM-porting thief.

TD Ameritrade seems to be SMS-based too -- right?

Schwab [seems to say](https://www.schwab.com/schwabsafe) SMS as well, but their page doesn't really get into it, and I think I saw somewhere else that they support physical tokens or the Symantec app. (No link because I closed the tab already, oops.)

Fidelity: [SMS or Symantec app](https://www.fidelity.com/security/extra-security-login), hopefully not both.

Interactive Brokers: hardware key or some custom phone app (Symantec again?). Also [someone says](https://old.reddit.com/r/investing/comments/9bpdse/do_all_the_big_brokerages_use_key_tokens_and_what/e557faa/) they can do facial recognition on an iphone app, which would be cool but not something I could use just now.

It baffles me that seemingly nobody supports either Yubikey or Google Auth (except uselessly like Vanguard apparently does for Yubikey). The Symantec app has poor reviews, and my prior for their security is considerably lower than Google's.

Any suggestions? Thanks!

(Background: I have a lump sum to invest in index funds and such. It's been sitting around a little while as I was too lazy/afraid to start investing. Now it seems foolish for me to not at least start averaging in. I know, don't time the market, but this is where I am now. So it looks like from the above I should resign myself to Symantec and try Fidelity, IB, or maybe Schwab if Schwab was giving the wrong impression in their vague security page. If there's someone supporting Google Auth or Yubikey, I already have those.)
